reviewText: I didn't care for this one. I got it because LDP was in it but he has better ones.Too much senseless violence.The acting was good but just not my kind of movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: EXTREME JUSTICEI have always been a fan of the Lou, which is Lou Diamond Phillips. I have to get everything that the man does because if I am a fan I support you. This film was about a special secret task force inside the LAPD. Of course since that PD is a very infamous place this all makes sense. This film is full of good actors and some cool action moments. After rewatching this recently I had to write something up on it.The film follows a young rookie cop [LDP] Jeff Powers as he keeps getting into trouble taking chances the department doesn't like. At the same time a special unit inside the force called S.I.S. loses a man during an operation and needs a replacement. The look to young Powers since one of the leaders [Scott Glenn] knew him. He gladly joins up but soon realizes he is in over his head once he sees how they operate. It turns out these guys wait for the crimes to actually take place so they can get justifiable kills. These leads to one event in which a woman is raped and Powers can't handle what this team is about.Lou is excellent here as he always is and plays the hot head rookie just as well as the guy who does not like what is going on around him. Of course Scott Glenn is great as the friend turned enemy who plays with the young's head for as long as he can. The rest of the cast is great as well and the film flows nicely thanks to director Mark Lester. I will admit that the film is not original and at times the script needed some better dialogue but still I liked it.This is a good flick that I would recommend to anyone looking to check out a police action/drama. Lou Diamond Phillips is great as he always is as is Scott Glenn. Not the best movie ever for sure but a good one none the less. Like I said The Lou is in it, that should be enough right there.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This ultra-violent, scary yarn of LA cops drifting out of control (and then some) offers great work from actor Scott Glenn and director Mark Lester. Glenn plays the leader of the secret hunter/tracker police unit who would much rather exterminate than incarcerate. Lester found a cold, clear-eye for the material and more than matched his exciting (and otherwise humorous) work on Arnold's Commando. There is very little to laugh at in Extreme Justice; a film that becomes more and more horrifying as it moves along. If you like hard nosed 70-80s cop/action flicks, then this one is probably for you. Extreme Justice is about as brutal & intense as any commercial film I can think of from the era, while the story delivers a real gut punch that haunt me to this day.
summary: Little seen but VERY HARD HITTING!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have always [almost] admired Scott Glenn and Lou Diamond Phillips.  But this story of rogue cops [and there may more reality than we care to admit] allowing the perps to commit the crime in order to have a justifiable killing is a bit gross.As I contend, movies are just entertainment for the most part, but you sure love to hate these characters.I normally don't like anything to happen to Scott's character but I thought he got justice done to him.And yes, again, who made man God.  Men like to think that their word is law but, boy, think again.I guess I want to say, I am glad not to be in that position but the perps need a bit of chastizement barring innocent victims, let the vigilantes be killers and not protected law enforcers.Ah well, this is not a movie for teen-agers [they already have tooo many ideas of their own and not all are practical]- for mature? audiences only.

reviewText: On boy. Lou Diamond Phillips looks like a sissy with his girly-man hair. This supposed Special Unit goes driving around in unmarked cop cars easy to follow. The bad-guys spout the usual foul-mouthed street profanity. Ahhh--- the setups are really stupid. The cop-talk is worse than the perp talk. Oh well. Sucks. Don't bother with this, unless you take it out from a library.

reviewText: Lance Uppercut, Zap Rowsdower, Skylord Harris, and now...Jeff Powers. When one thinks of an action hero, one desires a name of authority whose actions are full of piss and vinegar. In addition to this tough exterior he must also maintain a level of human understanding, giving him a perfect B grade ying and yang. Well Lou Diamond Phillips has certainly stepped up to the plate and hit one out of the park. Not just out of the park but a line drive straight into the face of the Scatman. We loved him as a sensitive peace loving fellow in Labamba, but that performance has nothing on the greatness of Jack Powers. Sporting some type of hybrid 90's Mullet, Lou Diamond Phillips steps on the screen looking like a human version of Chief Wooden-Head...if he played a rogue cop. 2012 is proving to be a groundbreaking year in the library of Sid the Elf. By being exposed to near lethal doses of Lorenzo Lamas and Lou Diamond Phillips, we have just expanded the B viewing market by a very impressive 6.9%. Both these gentlemen will be seeing a lot of studio space in the near future. An endeavor we're more then happy to partake in.Right off the bat you can tell you just stumbled upon some fantastic 90's rogue cop B. All films in this genre have nearly the same exact plot except the actors are swapped out. Lou Diamond plays a hot shot young cop named Jeff Powers. Powers doesn't play by anybody's rules including his own. Hence this attitude lands his getting booted off the force after being told "you're a loose cannon Powers!" A staple phrase in any good rogue cop B. After his discharge he's recruited by an old pal named Dan Vaughn, who looks like a cross breed of Chuck Norris and David Carradine, who has an interesting job position available. He makes Powers part of an underground division of the LAPD who are allowed to kill any criminal they choose. This gang of Cowboys seems to be a perfect fit however quickly prove to be too dirty for Powers. When he decides to go against the gang it officially becomes "go time" Izzy Mandelbaum style. In the end there is a hilarious bare knuckle brawl between Powers and Vaughn that is on par with any great finale we've ever seen. These two throw each other through a regular door, sliding glass door, wall, and barn door all while pounding each others heads in. Obviously Lou Diamond comes out the ultimate victor and leaves the the crew of flunkies in his rear view.After viewing Extreme Justice we were left with was a new appreciation for Mr. Lou Diamond Phillips. He's actually a good actor, but in this case he was the perfect B participant we had hoped for. All you have to do is take one glance at the cover, which looks like a picture that typically would be found on the back of the box. It's so B that you really have no other choice except to view what's inside. Among all the 90's B concepts there are, the rogue cop idea is one of the finest available. The only thing this film lacked, with most from the time period have excess in, is a lot of martial arts. Usually every cop and criminal will burst out into roundhouse kicks and karate chops, but not this time. We could only assume the mega mullet sported by Lou would and martial arts would be too powerful a combo to catch on film. The cameras would probably combust rendering the footage useless. Not to fear though. There is plenty of punches thrown and shots fired to entertain B fans of all walks of life. So instead of screaming "Ritchiiiiiiiiie" we could only end with "Powerrrrrrrrs!"
Title: N/A
